Hi Julian,

That's great, thanks! That's interesting that you highlighted t=
he fact
that EASy is more interested in A-Life. I suppose my interests are
=
starting to lean more towards A-Life as well... but I'm not well
versed eno=
ugh in the subject matter yet to know exactly where it
deviates significant=
ly from "adaptive neural networks" research.

Are there other Universities =
that you feel are more in-line with the
A-Life focus of the EASy programme?=


Cheers,
Mike

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Julian Togelius" <julian@...>=
 wrote:
>
> Mike,
> 
> You could also look at Simon Lucas' or Riccardo Poli=
's groups at
> University of Essex:
> http://dces.essex.ac.uk/staff/lucas/
=
> http://dces.essex.ac.uk/staff/poli/
> 
> And I must of course also recomm=
end the institution where me and
> Faustino Gomez currently work, IDSIA in =
Lugano:
> http://www.idsia.ch
> We do plenty of research in evolutionary co=
mputation and related
> fields, both in Juergen Schmidhuber's and Luca Gamb=
ardella's group.
> 
> I think you should not constrain yourself to English-=
speaking
> countries. Any good research lab will have a very international
=
> workforce and outlook, and the working language will be English.
> Myself=
, I speak English at work and (very bad) Italian in the
> supermarkets...
>=
 
> You should only look at funded PhD positions that pay you a salary you
=
> can live on. The way it works is that professors apply for grants for
> s=
pecific projects from funding agencies, and if they obtain their
> grant th=
ey employ the best person they can find as a PhD student or
> postdoc. Typi=
cally, it does not matter where you come from (though
> there are exception=
s).
> 
> I did my MSc at Sussex as well, and while it is a good program, it=
 is
> quite ALife-oriented.
> 
> Good luck with your studies and research!
=
> Julian
> 
> 2008/8/12 Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>:
> > Mike,
> >
> > I=
'd guess there are others in the group with similar questions so I
> > thin=
k it's probably useful to the group. (By the way, by "Adaptive
> > Networks=
," I assume you are referring to adaptive neural networks?)
> >
> > In any =
case, another option is the University of Texas at Austin,
> > which is whe=
re I did my Ph.D. under Prof. Risto Miikkulainen, who has
> > a leading gro=
up in the area:
> >
> > http://nn.cs.utexas.edu
> >
> > Another good lab is=
 Prof. Jordan Pollack's DEMO Lab at Brandeis:
> >
> > http://www.demo.cs.br=
andeis.edu/
> > http://www.cs.brandeis.edu/~pollack/
> >
> > However, Jorda=
n tells me that he will be renaming and revamping his
> > lab soon, so it w=
ill no longer be called "DEMO." However, it is
> > undoubtedly still a good=
 place to be.
> >
> > There are some newer places too with groups led by ne=
w professors,
> > including Prof. Bobby Bryant's "Neuroevolution and Behavi=
or
> > Laboratory" at the University of Nevada at Reno
> > (http://nebl.cse=
.unr.edu/) and Prof. Josh Bongard's new group at the
> > University of Verm=
ont (http://www.cs.uvm.edu/~jbongard/).
> >
> > Prof. Hod Lipson at Cornell=
 formerly worked with Prof. Pollack and
> > runs the Cornell Computational =
Synthesis Lab:
> >
> > http://ccsl.mae.cornell.edu/
> >
> > However, that l=
ab is a focused on emergent phenomena in general, with
> > a broader scope =
than some of the others.
> >
> > One other important group is Prof. Dario F=
loreano's Laboratory of
> > Intelligent Systems. This lab is in Switzerland=
, so I am not sure if
> > it conducts its day-to-day work in English (it mi=
ght), but in any case
> > it is very prominent in the area:
> >
> > http://=
lis.epfl.ch/
> >
> > Not all these groups have an explicit focus on neural =
networks, but
> > most have done some good work with them.
> >
> > Note tha=
t any Ph.D. program in North America should be willing to
> > support you f=
inancially if you get in.
> >
> > ken
> >
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.c=
om, "frayn.michael" <frayn.michael@> wrote:

=

> >>=
 England) to do their MSc in Evolutionary & Adaptive Systems.

aunting because of the cost. Unfortunately, I am not aware of

er Universities that would be interested in funding a PhD of
> >> such rese=
arch focuses (let alone would be able to comprehensively
> >> support stude=
nts along the way). This assumes, of course, that my MSc

cessful and I come up with a research question worthy of
> >> funding.
> >>=

 Europe) that may be appropriate to do such a PhD in. These are the

es I'm familiar with now:

 of Sussex

t directly related to NEAT but I couldn't think of

is a

roup, then please just point me in the right

st about this again here. Apologies if it's
